I live with my mother in Brewer-street, Somers Town - I was employed in sewing shoes at the prisoner's house - I have heard him tell his wife to go out, and if she said "No," he said, "Do go this time, there is 10s. to pay for rent, and I have had a very short week" - I heard him say so on the Monday before the 10th of February - Caroline Jones is my sister.

CAROLINE JONES -
GUILTY .* Aged 20.
Confined Ten Months .

WILLIAM JOHN JONES -
NOT GUILTY .

724.
JOSEPH HALEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of March , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
William Thompson
, from his person; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

WILLIAM THOMPSON. I live in Rood-lane. On the 9th of March, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I was walking along Chiswell-street
- I received information and missed my handkerchief, which I had had a few minutes before - I took the prisoner, and gave him in charge - it was a red silk handkerchief.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Has it been found? A. No - I did not see any body run - a gentleman was with me, but he is not here - I was near Finsbury-square at the time - I took the prisoner close to me.

EDWARD WILLIAMS
. I am clerk at a Manchester warehouse, in Wood-street, Cheapside - I was in Chiswell-street, and saw the prisoner and another following the prosecutor and his friend - I thought the prisoner was making too familiar with the prosecutor's coat - I saw him lift the tail of it up, and then take out the handkerchief - it was a red one, but I was not near enough to observe whether it was silk or cotton - I gave notice to the prosecutor - he turned and took hold of the prisoner, who was not half a yard from him - when the prisoner took the handkerchief out, he passed it behind him towards his companion, who was on the left side of him.

Cross-examined. Q. How near were you to the prisoner? A. About twenty yards - I was on the other side of the way - it wanted about twenty minutes to eleven o'clock - I crossed over and told the prosecutor - I did not see what became of the other man - I did not see any one run away - I said I supposed the prisoner might have put it into his pocket - I saw him take the handkerchief - if I had looked after the other man, as well as the prisoner, I might not have taken one of them - the street was full of people.

ROBERT STEWART
(City police-constable, No. 54). I was called, and the prisoner was given into my custody - I found nothing on him.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going to my aunt's to dinner - the witness came across the road, touched the prosecutor and said, "This man has taken your handkerchief out of your pocket" - I said, "You are mistaken;" but the prosecutor said, "I certainly must give more credence to this gentleman than to you" - I was taken - nothing was found on me.

ABRAHAM HART
. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark 's office - I know him to be the man.

GUILTY .* Aged 23. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
OLD COURT. - Wednesday, April 14th.
First Middlesex Jury, Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

725.
JOHN PAGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , 80 yards of silk, value 12l., of
James Shudi Broadwood
, and another, in their dwelling-house .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS HENRY THOMPSON
. I am a policeman. On the 5th of April, I was on duty in Marylebone-lane, and saw the prisoner in company with another man, (not Willard), he had a roll of something under his arm, and was talking to Moss, a Jew, who keeps a clothes-shop - in consequence of what Moss told me, I watched them to the shop of Barnett, a clothes-dealer, then to the shop of Lazarus - the prisoner still had the goods under his arm - I accosted him, and asked, what he had got there? - he said a piece of silk - I asked if it was his own - he said it was - I asked what he was? - he said, a porter - I asked who to - he said he was a job porter - I said I had seen him go to several shops, which I thought was not right, and asked what colour the silk was? - he said he believed it was red- I asked if he knew how many yards there were - he said he did not - I took hold of him, and the other man, who was afterwards discharged - in going to the station-house, I asked where he lived? - he said, at Bayswater - at the station-house, I asked if he really lived at Bayswater? - he said, "Yes," and he would tell me all about it - I told him to reserve what he had to say, for the magistrate - he said, he was at work at Messrs. Broadwood's, and a man named Willard, who was an under clerk, had given him the silk to sell - he produced a piece of paper Willard had given him, to make a return on it, as to what the silk sold for.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. He gave you Willard's address? A. Yes; I afterwards saw Willard, and made him write his name on a piece of paper, to see if the handwriting was the same, and it was.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did he say Willard called on him to sell the silk, or what? A. He said, Willard gave it him to sell - nothing was said about calling on him - Willard is an under store keeper at Broadwood's; and the prisoner was a French polisher, employed there.

FREDERICK SNOOK
. I am a tailor, and live in Wigmore-street, at Mr. Romanell's. The prisoner called at Mr. Romanell's shop, on Friday evening, and told me he had a piece of silk to dispose of, and he wanted clothes in exchange, part in clothes, and part in money - he brought the silk - I showed it our shopman, who told me to have nothing at all to do with it.

THOMAS AYLING
. I am in the employ of Messrs. James Shudi and Thomas Broadwood; the house of business is in Pulteny-street, St. James's, Westminster
- I cannot swear to this silk, but I know the wrapper it is in. The prisoner was employed about Messrs. Broadwood's premises, as a French-polisher , under his uncle, not as their servant.
Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known him? A. About four years - I know nothing dishonest of him.

HENRY HENMAN
. I am in the employ of Harding and Smith, silk-mercers, Pall Mall. This is one of three pieces of silk which I sent to Broadwood's on the 25th of March - it is a double sarsnet, used by pianoforte makers, and is wider than is generally used - there are eighty yards of it, worth 12l. - this is the wrapper I sent the silk in to Broadwood's - and the mark on the block of the silk corresponds with the mark on the paper.

Prisoner's Defence. On Friday, Willard came into the shop at Mr. Broadwood's, and said he wanted to speak to me. I went to the bottom of the stairs. He said he had a piece of silk given him by the gentleman (who served Messrs. Broadwood with silk), as a Christmas-box, and he had had it some time - he asked if I knew who was likely to buy it. I said, "No," but if it was his own, and he came honestly by it, the Jews would soon purchase it - he said, "As you go home, you pass several shops, would yougo and inquire?" I said I would; and, as I went home, I called at the Jew's, and said, I knew a person who had silk to dispose of - he said, "Let me see it; if it suits, I will buy it." On Saturday, Willard asked if I had spoken to any body? I said, "Yes, and they would look at it"- he brought the silks in his hand to the pay table, in Windmill-street, about half-past six o'clock. I went with him to a public-house - he asked the bar-maid to give him a pen and ink - he wrote me the direction where I was to call. I was not to ask any price for it, but to go, and let him know if it suited the party, and he would call himself, and arrange the price. I went to the shop about the silk, and directly I opened it, I thought it was not his own. The Jew said, if it was gown silk, he would buy it - I was bringing it away, and when I got to Marylebone, (Proctor, my shopmate, was with me,) a Jew caught hold of my arm, and asked if I wanted to buy any thing? - then the policeman caught hold of me, and asked what I had? I said, "Silk." I said it was not my own. I said I was a polisher - I did not say I was a porter - at the station-house I said, "I am drawn into this, and dare say I shall suffer for it, although innocent."

BROOK PAYNE
. I am the prisoner's uncle. He is in my employ - I am a French-polisher - Willard is in Mr. Broadwood's employ, and is called under-foreman, I believe - I remember seeing him on Saturday, the 5th of April - he had a paper parcel in his hand - a light-brown parcel, from ten to eighteen inches - I spoke to him - Willard was in the habit of going into my shop to fetch young men out, to go on errands - the prisoner has been in my employ five years, and always attended to my business.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Willard was employed at Broadwood's? A. Yes; and my nephew was employed on their premises by me - I was employed there by contract - I know they use silk in their business, but I cannot say it was silk - it was a paper parcel that I saw - I never knew a mercer give away silk as a Christmas-box - it might be so for all I know.
THOMAS HENRY THOMPSON re-examined. I produce the paper the prisoner gave me.
JURY. Q. When you took the prisoner was the piece of silk rolled up in the same manner as it is now? A. Exactly the same.
JURY to T. AYLING. Q. Could a person employed under another have access to the silk, he being a French-polisher? A. Not without my consent or Willard's, who had access to it.
NOT GUILTY .

726.
WILLIAM STEWARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of March , 1 ham, value 6s. , the goods of
Frederick Pamphilon
.

FREDERICK PAMPHILON. I keep a cheese-shop in Skinner-street, Somers Town
. On the 27th of March, while I was standing behind the counter, I saw the glimpse of two men pass the window, and heard a voice say, "Tom, here's a ham" - my man ran out, and the ham was gone - one of the policemen took the prisoner.

THOMAS MITCHELL
. I am a policeman. The prisoner passed by me with the ham under his coat - he went into a dark court, and my brother officer took him - I found the ham in a dark passage where he went down, and dropped it - we secured him as he came out.

HENRY MARTIN
. I am a policeman. I was standing at the corner of Cromer-street - the prisoner passed with a ham partly concealed under his coat - I followed and took him into custody - the ham was found two yards from him.
Prisoner. I hope for mercy.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Three Months .

727.
RICHARD SMITH
was indicted was
stealing, on the 20th of March , 40lbs. of lead, value 5s.; the goods of
Robert Briggs
and another, and fixed to a building , against the Statute, &c.

JOHN SHEPHERD
. I am a policeman. On the 20th of March, about ten minutes after nine o'clock in the evening I was in Cock-alley, Norton-falgate
- I saw a boy standing at the back of Briggs's premises - I suspected him - another joined him soon after, and when they saw us, they made off- neither of them was the prisoner - I sent the constable, and took the two boys into custody - I found a piece of lead where the boys stood - I went up stairs in a house in Cock-alley, in half an hour - I found the prisoner in bed, and this piece of lead lying about two yards from him; another boy was in bed with him - we took them both into custody - they said they knew nothing of the lead - it was concealed under the cinders in the garret - we took five persons who were in the house into custody - next morning I fitted the lead to Briggs's premises, and it tallied exactly; also the piece which I found where the boys stood - I took them all five before the magistrate - they were all discharged except the prisoner - I was present at the examination - I saw the magistrate sign the deposition which was read over to the prisoner - no threat or promise was held out to him - this is Mr. Broughton's handwriting (read) -"At the second examination, the prisoner said, the other persons knew nothing about the lead, for that he found it, and carried it there."

ALEXANDER SCOTT
. I am a policeman. Shepherd's evidence is correct.

THOMAS BREESE
. I am foreman to Robert Briggs and another - the back of their premises opens into Cock-alley - I had seen the lead secure on the top of the manufactory before this happened - the party had got on the roof from the outside - it is a great height - they must have had a ladder to get up - the lead appeared quite bright and fresh - there is a soot shed adjoining the premises - they must have got on the top of the shed; the lead was cut in a very unworkmanlike manner - I have seen the prisoner about the neighbourhood.
Prisoner's Defence. About eight o'clock at night, I went to bed - I went outside to do what I wanted, and saw the lead lying on the ruins - I took it up stairs and went to bed.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

728.
THOMAS WILLIAM TOTTENHAM PRESCOTT
was indicted for
feloniously forging an order for the payment of 50l., with intent to defraud
Richard Henry Cox
and others .
2nd COUNT for uttering the same with the like intent.
Other Counts, varying the manner of stating the charge.
MR. BODKIN conducted the Prosecution.

JAMES POWELL
. I am clerk to Richard Henry Cox and two others. On the 14th of December last, I saw the prisoner at our house - we had a correspondent at that time, named
Captain Gordon
- the prisoner produced this letter to me - I asked him to favour me with his name - he said his name was Wainwright - I said, "Captain Wainwright?" - he answered, "Yes;" and added, "Not
Captain Wainwright
, late of the 47th" - I then told him, as the order was to pay the money on the sale of the stock, I could not pay it him then; but that he must come again in a few days' time, when the stock would be sold - he asked what day he should come - I think Wednesday was mentioned - this was on a Saturday - he remonstrated at not being paid then, and stated that he had received the order from Captain Gordon for a particular purpose, and that it was of a pressing nature - I said I was sorry to put him to inconvenience, but I could not pay the money till the stock was sold - he then left - I saw him again on the 18th of December; I think it was Wednesday (it was a few days after this) - he asked if I was ready then to pay the money - I said, "Yes," and asked him his Christain name - he replied, "Charles" - I then filled up the order, conceiving he was the proper person for whom it was intended, and whom he represented himself to be - this is the order (looking at it) - he signed it in my presence - this order which he signed was the authority for paying the money - in the course of our business, the party applying would be called on to sign such an order as this before it was paid - we do not pay the money in my department of the house - we should not part with the money unless that cheque had been signed.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Have you ever seen Captain Gordon since he wrote that letter? A. No; I know nothing of the prisoner except in this transaction - we were agents for Captain Wainwright, late of the 47th- Captain Gordon is also of the 47th - Captain Wainwright's name is not Charles - we were agents for him while he was in the 47th - he is on half-pay now, and not in any regiment.

Q. The prisoner brought you that letter which was your voucher or authority for payment of this money? A. Yes, on his signing the cheque; the letter was my authority to charge it to Captain Gordon's account - if Captain Gordon asked for a voucher, I should have to produce the letter and the receipt - the letter is my authority, supported by the receipt.

Q. Do you use and treat that paper which you have produced in any other way than a receipt for the payment of money, which Captain Gordon had previously ordered to be paid? A. I treat it as a draft in acknowledgment of the money - Captain Charles Wainwright, if there is such a person, had no money in our hands to give an order to receive - the letter does not mention any Christain name - I am not aware that there is such a person as Charles Wainwright, who has any money in our hands to which an order could apply - I do not know all the clients of the house - I paid the money on the faith of Captain Gordon's letter to the party who said he was Captain Wainwright - Captain Gordon is at Mullingar - he corresponds with us from Ireland.

MR. BODKIN. Q. The letter of Captain Gordon was the authority on which you sold out his stock? A. It was; the cashier pays the money on authority of the draft - he does not see the original order, when he pays the money - he pays it on production of the draft which the prisoner signed - my handwriting is on the draft.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. The cashier knows your handwriting on the draft? A. Yes; my initials are on it - that forms a voucher or authority to the cashier to pay the money - he would not pay it unless it was marked by the clerk, who has charge of the account.
COURT. Q. If the draft was not signed, your initials alone would not be the authority to pay it? A. No; the draft must be signed before the cashier would pay it.

JURY. Q. Did you consider you were paying the money to Captain Wainwright late of the 47th? A. No: I did not pay the money - I knew Captain Wainwright, late of the 47th, and supposed the prisoner to be another Captain Wainwright.

FREDERICK WEEDON
. I am cashier to Messrs. Cox and Co. I paid this draft on the day it bears date, from the funds of Cox and Co.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner on the Wednesday preceding the examination - I do not remember the day of the month - I took him in Titchbourn-street, Coventry-street - I knew him as Prescott - I met him accidentally in the street - he made a stop and said, "How do you do?" - I said, "I had been looking for you some time, I want you" - he said, "For what?" - I said,"I have a warrant against you" - he said, "What is it for?" - I said, "For obtaining money by fraud" - he asked where it was from - I said, "From Cox and Greenwood" - he said, "I know nothing about it - I will go there with you" - I said, "Do you know a person named Wainwright?"- he said, "I do - how much is it for?" - I said, "I really do not remember the sum" - he said, "Oh, it is for 50l.: here, I will give you the money" - I declined to take it, and he offered to go to Cox and Greenwood, to take the money there - he also wished me to take him to the Solicitor's in Harley-street, and he would give the money there - I declined to go there with him, and took him to the office - he complained of his friends neglecting him, and said he was obliged to do it - he had no other means of living.

CAPTAIN
HENRY MAXWELL WAINWRIGHT
. I was lately a Captain in the 47th. I am acquainted with Captain Gordon, who is in Ireland, and have been so for eighteen years - I never heard of any other Captain Wainwright with whom Captain Gordon was acquainted - I have left the 47th three years - I have been acquainted with the 47th since 1808 - I was in it twenty years - I never knew any other Captain Wainwright, but myself - I do not know of any Captain Charles Wainwright, in the army - Captain Gordon was at my house about half a year ago - I did not authorize any person to sign that order for me - I knew nothing of the transaction till after this discovery.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You knew nothing of this cheque? A. No; my name is not Charles - I was acquainted with the prisoner about three years ago - he knew my Christain name is not Charles, and he knew I had belonged to the 47th - Captain Gordon is in health as far as I know - he is with his regiment at Mullingar - I have notseen him for half a year - the signature to this letter is his handwriting - I do not know what acquaintance he may have made within the last half-year - I have been all over India, and never knew any Captain Wainwright, but myself - there may be one in the militia that I do not know - I knew a Mr. Campbell in the regiment, intimately - he was acquainted with Captain Gordon - he died suddenly - I do not think Campbell knew the prisoner.
MR. BODKIN. Q. During your acquaintance with the prisoner, did you ever know him as Captain Wainwright? A. No.
JURY. Q. Did you expect such an order as that from Captain Gordon? A. None - I do not live at the British Hotel, nor are my letters directed there.
(Letter read.)
"To Captain Wainwright, British Hotel, Cockspur-street.
"Mullingar Barracks, 10th December, 1833.

"Gentlemen, - Please to pay Captain Wainwright 50l., and charge the same to my account; giving directions to your broker to sell out from the 4 per cents a sum equivalent to meet that, by virtue of the power of attorney you hold from me.
"To Messrs. Cox and Co."JOHN GORDON,
"1st Captain 47th Regt."
- POWELL. Our house are agents to Captain Wainwright - we had a power of attorney to sell this stock for Captain Gordon.

Prisoner's Defence. My Lord, and Gentlemen of the Jury, although a gentleman by birth and education, I am so paralyzed by the disgrace and ignominy of my present situation, that I have not power to address you verbally, although my life or liberty might be the forfeit of my silence. I must therefore trust to this less effective mode of expressing to you the truth of my case. My father was a man of high respectability, nearly related to the banker and the baronet of the same name; he was an East India director, and I need not add therefore of good fortune. The wants of a man are more or less in proportion to his station in life. My life was that of a gentleman moving in the best society, and to keep a footing with those I associated with, required pecuniary means of considerable extent, and those means were supplied by the hand of a kind and affectionate parent, while my father lived; unfortunately he died, in 1832, and then, for the first time, it was found that his affairs were insolvent, and I, of course, destitute and pennyless. I was of no profession, for I had quitted the army in my father's lifetime, and of course had great difficulty to live and support myself and wife. I had some trifling assistance from friends, but that of course could not last, and I was unable to extricate myself from my embarrassments, and was obliged to keep myself secret and change my name; and, for fear of being arrested, took the name of Wainwright, and went to Ireland, where a friend of mine was with his regiment; this friend was Captain Duncan Campbell, of the 47th: he knew me both by my own name of Prescott, and by the assumed name of Wainwright; and, as I had held a commission in a dragoon regiment, I had (although retired from the service) been generally since styled Captain, which accounts for my being called Captain Wainwright, as I had been called Captain Prescott; and so friendly was Captain Campbell with me, that he advised me to continue the same name, and I corresponded with him by that name when I left Ireland and came to London. At length, my distress and difficulty increasing, I wrote to him for the loan of 50l., and an order came for the amount from a Captain Gordon; this order was addressed to me as "Captain Wainwright, British Hotel, Cockspur-street, London." I there received it, as I had received other letters, and then, as has been stated, presented it for payment on the one day, and received the amount on a subsequent day. Now, gentlemen, where is the forgery? Was I not the person who wrote to Captain Campbell? If I were not the person intended to have the money, who was? My brother-in-law's name, 'tis true, is Wainwright; his name is not however Charles Wainwright, but Henry Maxwell Wainwright; he lives at Aske, near Farnham, in Surrey, forty miles from London. Did he write to Captain Campbell or Captain Gordon for the loan of money? I humbly submit that it is the duty of the prosecutors, before they ask for a verdict of guilty, to convince you that I am not the person who was intended to have this money, by producing the person who was. Captain Gordon intended it for the person who wrote to Captain Campbell; and I am that person, otherwise I should not have received the letter addressed to me. Again, when I presented the order the amount was not paid, but I was directed to return some days after. Would a guilty man have returned? No; he would have sent a messenger, or done any act rather than ventured again to the same spot. I had no such fear; I was doing nothing wrong; and I returned and signed the draft which the clerk placed before me. If any other person had been in expectation of such order for 50l., that person would have gone to the British Hotel, for the letter, and to Cox and Greenwood's to inquire. Is there any proof that any, even the least, inquiry was made there for the letter? and if any other person but myself had expected it, and had been disappointed, would not that person have been a witness here to-day, and complained that he had been defrauded of the 50l. which had been sent him? Gentlemen, the facts resolve themselves into this - I was distressed, and in fear of my creditors, and to avoid arrest, assumed the name of Captain Charles Wainwright: my friend, Captain Campbell, knew it, and corresponded with me accordingly. I wrote to him for a loan, which was sent me by his friend; and I signed the name I had assumed, and by which I was known in the transaction. What forgery is this? What was my conduct when apprehended? - The officer said he had a warrant against me for fraud: I said I knew nothing of it. It was true; I knew of no fraud. He said it was from Cox and Greenwood's. Knowing I had committed no fraud, I offered to go there with him, but he refused to allow me: and then he mentioned the name of Wainwright; on which I instantly named the transaction, and the sum received. Did this look like guilt, gentlemen? No; I had nothing to conceal. I had received the money intended for me, and supposed, because I had not repaid it, that I was to be arrested for the amount, and, of course, was anxious to avoid a prison, not merely on account of the 50l., but for fear of other creditors. I certainly complained of the neglect of my friends, and my want of means to live,and said, I was obliged to do as I had done, referring thereby to the loan I had made of the 50l. These are the facts, my Lord and Gentlemen, and I trust you will see that in writing the name by which I was known to the person to whom I wrote for the money, I did nothing dishonest, or fraudulent; and with full assurance on your judgment, I rely on your verdict of acquittal.

JURY to WILLIAM BALLARD. Q. Was it possible for the prisoner to mistake you for a sheriff's officer? A. He knew me as an officer of Marlbourough-street - I have been so ten or twelve years - I never knew him go by the name of Wainwright.
JAMES POWELL. No application has been made for this money in the name of Wainwright; nor has anybody claimed it - I should not have paid it to anybody but a person named Wainwright.
NOT GUILTY .

729.
RICHARD LENNOX
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of April , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
James Engleburt
, from his person .

JAMES ENGLEBURT. On the 3rd of April, about half-past nine o'clock, I was opposite Shoreditch church
- I felt a snatch at my pocket, turned round, and saw the prisoner walking before me - I ran before him and saw a handkerchief in his hand - he immediately passed it to another person, and I have not seen it since - I secured him immediately - I am certain he had it in his possession - I could not swear it was mine.

JAMES CHARLES WOLLER
. I was with the prosecutor who missed his handkerchief - he charged the prisoner with it - he appeared confused - I did not see it in his hand.

Prisoner's Defence. I knocked up against the gentleman, and he charged me with stealing his handkerchief - he searched me, but I had not got it - he let me go, then came after me again, and gave me in charge.

JAMES ENGLEBURT re-examined. Nobody else could have picked my pocket - no body else was near him - he was about three feet from me - my handkerchief was red, yellow, and black - I could discover the handkerchief he had was those colours, and fully believe it to be mine - I felt my pocket picked the moment before, and nobody was so near me as him - I saw it go out of his hand immediately - I can swear that no person was near me except the prisoner when I felt my pocket picked.

GUILTY. Aged 14. - Recommended to mercy . -
Confined Six Weeks .

730.
ELIZA BUTLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of March , 18 yards of ribbon, value 11s. , the goods of
Enoch Jones
.

WILLIAM HOLLIDAY
. I am shopman to Enoch Jones, a draper , in the City-road
. The prisoner came to the shop on the 4th of March - she bought a yard of ribbon and paid for it - I saw her take this ribbon, and put it under her shawl - I took her to Mr. Jones - she dropped it when she was accused of stealing it.
ENOCH JONES. I am the master of the shop - this is my ribbon - I heard something fall, and found it at her feet.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined One Month .

731.
JOHN BARKER
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

WILLIAM OLDHAM
. I am shopman to
William Sowter
, a builder . I had known the prisoner about a month in the employ of Mr. Jay, the foreman at Sowter's - I considered he was in the employ of Jay as usual - he came to our yard, and said he had come from Mr. Jay for some nails to go to Aldersgate-street - knowing Mr. Sowter was building there, I gave him between two and three thousand nails to take there, believing Jay had sent him for them.

NELSON CHALCROFT
. On the 8th of March , I met the prisoner coming out of the yard with some nails - he said he had got a bit of a job of his own, and had come after a few nails, and not to say any thing about it.

JOHN JAY
. I am foreman to Mr. Sowter. I did not send the prisoner for any nails on the 8th of March - I have known him two or three years - he bore a very good character.

GUILTY. Aged 34. - Recommended to mercy . -
Confined Six Weeks .
NEW COURT, Wednesday, April 16, 1834.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

732.
ABRAHAM GREEN
and
ELIZABETH GREEN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of March , 2 violins, value 15s. , the goods of
George Adam Barnes
.

GEORGE ADAM BARNES. I live in the Shepherdess-walk, City-road
, and deal in furniture . On Monday, the 17th of March, I missed two violins - I had seen them safe about six o'clock on the Saturday evening - I went to a pawnbroker's to make inquiries, and saw Elizabeth Green, the prisoner, there offering one of my violins to pawn - the pawnbroker said it had been pawned on the Saturday night by a tall young man, and had been taken out again - I asked how she got it - she said her husband bought it of a tall young man - she described him as the pawnbroker had done - I sent for an officer, who took her - she sent for her husband, who gave the same account - he was then taken before the magistrate, and let out on bail - he called on me in about a week, and said a friend of his had picked up part of a duplicate of a violin - we went to a pawnbroker's in St. Luke's, and found this other violin, which is mine.
NOT GUILTY .

733.
JOHN EDWARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 1 pair of boots, value 5s. , the goods of
Josiah Storer
and another.

ERNEST STORER. I live with my brother, Josiah Storer and another in Whitechapel
- they are boot and shoemakers . On the 7th of April, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, I was standing at their door, and these boots were presented to me - they are my brother's - I took them - they had hung inside our door.

JAMES WILD
(police-constable R 141). I was in Whitechapel in plain clothes - I saw the prisoner and two others at the prosecutor's window - I went to the corner of Petticoat-lane - I watched them a minute or two - they went to the shop window and then to the foot path, and then to the window again - I went to the foot path, and saw the prisoner put his hand on the rail that goes round the shop, and take off this pair of boots - he came past me - Icaught at him - he dropped the boots - I took them up - he stooped - I missed my hold of him - he ran up the butchers' row, and there he threw off his own shoes, and ran into Somerset-street - I pursued and took him without losing sight of him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

734.
WILLIAM CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on April 7 , 1 silver spoon, value 20s. , the goods of
Peter Rainer
.

CHARLES WALTER
. I am valet to Peter Rainer, Esq. , of Albany, Piccadilly
. The prisoner was his groom , and occasionally assisted me to clean the plate - this spoon is my master's, but I did not miss it till the officer came to inquire about it: and on comparing it with those of the same pattern, I have no doubt of its being my master's, though the crest is partly taken off.

NATHANIEL BOARD
. I am foreman to a pawnbroker in Green-street, Leicester-square. This spoon was offered in pawn by
James Jennery
, on the 7th of April - I thought it was not right, and asked who he brought it from - he said from Mrs. Henderson - I sent him back to send the person to me - he did not return - I had occasion to go to Marlborough-street, and showed the spoon to Avis, the officer - on the following day the prisoner came to me - he said he had come for a spoon which had been left by an old man yesterday - I said he could not expect me to give it up to him, as he was not the person who left it - he said he would go and fetch the man who left it - he did so - I said I should not give it them - I sent for the officer, but he was not in the way - the prisoner went away, and came again, and said, when he came the second time, that he was surprised at my keeping the spoon, and he was rather impudent - I gave him in charge.

JAMES JENNERY. I am a coachman. I have known the prisoner some time - I was going to get half a pint of porter - he came to me and said, "I wish you would go on an errand for me" - I said, "What was it to do?" - he said"To pawn a spoon" - I said "I am not in the habit of doing such things" - he said he wanted 8s. for it - I took it to the pawnbroker's, and it was detained - I went and told him, and he said he would go to Mrs. Sanders, somewhere by Soho-square - I saw him the next day - he asked me if I would go down to the pawnbroker's - I went with him - he demanded it, and said he would swear it was his property.

GEORGE AVIS
. I am an officer. I had charge of the prisoner - this is the spoon - the prisoner said he would prove it was his own property, and that it and another were given to him by a Mrs. Howard.
Prisoner's Defence. I had Mrs. Sanders here, who would prove that she gave me the duplicate of the two spoons which had belonged to Mrs. Howard , with whom I lived before her husband died.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined One Year .

735.
WILLIAM BENSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of March , 91 yards of cloth, value 80l.; 8 waistcoats, value 5l.; 19 waistcoat-pieces, value 5l.; 4 coats, value 15l.; 11 yards of kerseymere, value 5l.; 4 yards of serge, value 12s.; 2 yards of velvet, value 36s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 30s.; and 2 fur collars, value 10s.; the goods of
William Broughton
, his master .

WILLIAM BROUGHTON. I am a tailor , and live in High Holborn
. The prisoner was in my employ up to the 19th of March - I went out that evening from ten minutes to a quarter past nine o'clock with
Thomas Leekey
- I left the prisoner in the shop - I gave him directions to clear the window, and shut up the shop - he asked me if I was going to Mr. Gibson 's, the Craven Arms - I said yes, I believed I should, and he said he should come as soon as he had closed - he did not come there, but about a quarter before ten o'clock, a man in the employ of Mr. Thwaites , came for me - I came home, and found my shop stripped of every thing that was moveable, almost: and two or three policemen were in the shop - when I went out there were ninety-one yards of cloth there, worth about 82l.; eight waistcoats, worth 5l.; nineteen waistcoat-pieces, worth 5l.; four coats, worth 15l.; and the other articles stated in the indictment - I have not seen any of them since - the prisoner was gone when I got home - there were no marks of violence on the door, as if any one had broken in - the prisoner did not sleep in my house - he generally came in the morning, but the police took him the next morning.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. These things would have formed a considerable bulk? A. Yes. I went out that evening with Mr. Leekey, who lives in the same house - we both took the house together - he is also a tailor - he is not in partnership with me - he has a weekly salary - I know these bills, which are headed "Leekey and Broughton"- we had been in partnership, but that had been dissolved six weeks before this robbery - on the 16th of January - none of these bills have been given out since, to my knowledge - Leekey was before the magistrate - I believe he stated that he was not a partner with me, but I was in such a state, I could attend to nobody's evidence but my own - sometimes the lock of my door does not catch if the window has not been shut right - I believe the door was found open one morning by a person who was in my employ - I have not been forced to open it with a poker - it is possible that if the window had not been shut right, a person might push the door open - there was nothing of mine found on the prisoner, or about him.
COURT. Q. Was it his business to leave the window and door secure? A. Yes; if he had shut the window, and placed the post right, the door would shut itself when he went out.

ANN BROUGHTON
. I am the prosecutor's wife - I went into the shop that evening, about a quarter before ten o'clock- I found every thing had been taken out of it - Bray had come up stairs about a quarter or twenty minutes before ten o'clock, and I asked him how he got in; and from what he told me, I went down to the shop - I found the shop-door ajar, but there was no appearance of its having been forced open - the tickets of prices which had been on the clothes, were strewed about the bottom of the window - they ought to have been in a drawer, or on the mantelpiece - I had never seen them so strewed about before - I had not been in the shop that evening from a quarter past nine o'clock, till a quarter before ten o'clock, but I had passed down the stair-case three times - there is a staircase door which leads into the shop, and each time I came down it was shut - it is usually kept open in the evening.

JOSEPH BRAY
. I am twelve years old - I know thenecessity of telling the truth - I lodge at Mr. Broughton's; but I am errand-boy at No. 29, St. Martin's-lane - I got home to Mr. Broughton's on the night in question, about a quarter before ten o'clock - as I was crossing the road opposite his shop, I saw a man outside pushing the door open - he looked round and saw me, and pulled the door to again - he then walked away towards Middle-row - I went in at the door which he had left ajar, and went up stairs - I met Mrs. Broughton on the stairs, and she asked me how I got in - I saw the shop-windows were empty, and the blocks were naked - the man who came out at the shop door was a tall man - I knew the prisoner before - I do not know whether he was the man who came out of the door - I did not see his face - he walked along, and another man, not so tall as he was, joined him.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had you lived in that house? A. I do not know, Sir - I believe about a month - I had seen the prisoner constantly going in and out - I leave my place in St. Martin's-lane at ten o'clock at night - my master had not given me a holiday, and sent me home earlier that night than usual - I do not know what time it was when I got to Mr. Broughton's; but my usual time of leaving St. Martin's-lane is ten o'clock - one of the men was a tall man - I do not know whether he was the prisoner - when Mrs. Broughton came into the shop, the door was shut - I shut it when I went in.
COURT. Q. Was the man who came out and shut the door taller or shorter, or about the same height as the prisoner? A. I think about the same height.

ELIZABETH LEEKEY
. I am the wife of
Thomas Leekey
. I lodge at the prosecutor's. I was at home that evening, and heard
Sarah Ward
, the servant, go down stairs about half-past nine o'clock - I then heard the stair-door shut, which makes a loud noise, and shakes my room - I sent my sister down stairs to know why the door was shut - that door leads from the stairs into the shop; and it is not a usual thing to shut it - I have been in the habit of coming down, if I heard any one in the shop, to see what was going on, and therefore that door was always left open - when I sent my sister down, she returned up again to me, and soon afterwards the prisoner came up, as soon as he had shut the shop - I did not see him shut the shop, but I heard it - he then came up stairs in consequence of my having sent my sister down to tell him I wanted to speak to him - he had promised to lend me a book, and I asked him for it - he said he had not got it; he had left it at Somers Town - he was finishing putting on his coat when he spoke to me - he then went out of my room, and shut my room door, which I never have shut - he wished me good night, and seemed in a bustle, as it was rather later than usual for him - Mrs. Broughton then came into my room, and the little boy came up - we all went down, and found the shop was stripped - I think from the time of the prisoner coming up stairs, and our going down and finding the shop stripped, was about two minutes - it might have been rather more, as I was working a bracelet, and was rather engaged upon it - the cloth that had been in the shop was all solid cloth and heavy - I do not think one man could have taken it away in two or three minutes.
MR. BROUGHTON. I should think it would have taken two men ten minutes to have taken away the property if they had known the place - it would take a stranger, I should think, a quarter of an hour.

JURY to ELIZABETH LEEKEY. Q. Was the prisoner in the habit of coming up to your room? A. He was in the habit of coming up at night, and saying he was going, and asking me to attend to the door; but I had not been at home till the last fortnight of his being there.
COURT. Q. When he came up in the evening, was he in the habit of shutting your door? A. I do not know that he has shut it - I remember he closed it once.

Cross-examined. Q. You have stated you heard the staircase door leading into the shop shut, and that it was always left open? A. Yes, by my wish it was; but it is a door that makes a noise when it shuts, as it does not catch well - it had lately been shut more frequently - I heard it shut that evening, as it shook my room - whoever went down stairs into the shop must have opened that door again - the prisoner said he lived at Somers Town.

SARAH WARD. I am servant to Mrs. Broughton. She sent me out that evening at twenty minutes before ten o'clock - when I went down the staircase door was shut, and I opened it, and went into the shop - there is no other way out of the house but at the shop door - the prisoner and a young man were in the shop - no other person - the young man went out of the shop as I went in - the prisoner did not go out - I think the young man was not so tall as the prisoner; but I did not see his face - I asked the prisoner if that was Robert - he said "No," it was a young man; and he said something else which I do not recollect - the prisoner was putting his coat on - I noticed the busts in the shop were without coats - I had never seen them off before - I went out and returned in about ten minutes - the shop was then full of policemen.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you been in the habit of noticing the shop at night? A. No: this was on a Wednesday night - I do not know that the prisoner had been in the habit of folding up the coats on Wednesday and Saturday evenings.
COURT. Q. Had you been in the shop on Wednesday and Saturday evenings? A. Yes - I never saw the busts without the coats before.
MR. BROUGHTON. It was not the prisoner's practice to fold up the coats on those nights.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he never fold up the coats that were in the shop? A. The coats which were on the busts were two that were made on purpose for them - I do not know that they were ever folded up, or taken off, but by myself - I am out in the evening sometimes; but when I came home, I must have seen if the busts had been without coats, as I passed close by them; and I never did see that - there are gas-lights in the shop - one of them continues burning a little all night.

HENRY BROWN
. I slept in Sydney-street, Somers Town, in the same bed with the prisoner - I went to bed that night about twelve o'clock, the prisoner had not then come home - I lay awake till a little after one o'clock- the prisoner then came home.

EDWARD SHAYLER
(police-constable S 187). I went to Sydney-street, and took the prisoner the next morning - I told him I wanted him on suspicion of being concerned in a robbery - he said, "Dear me, it is very strange ifthere has been a robbery at Mr. Broughton's, I left the shop safe last night, at half-past nine o'clock" - I said,"You are my prisoner, and must go with me to the station-house" - in going along, I asked him what time he got home? - he said, "Ask me no questions; I shall answer you none if you do" - I found nothing on him, nor in his room, connected with this robbery.
COURT to SARAH WARD. Q. How do you know it wanted twenty minutes to ten o'clock, when you went down into the shop? A. I looked at the dial in the shop,

Prisoner's Defence. The boy said they were two short men in frock coats, and I wore a dress coat. When Mr. Broughton and Mr. Leekey went out together, I was told to take the things down; it generally took me a quarter of an hour to do that. I had done about twenty-five minutes past nine o'clock. Mrs. Leekey then sent her sister down to ask me about a book I was to lend her - I said, I could not get it that night, as it was too far to go to Somers'-town, and return. I then went out, and slammed the door after me - Mr. Broughton knows that the door had been left open all night, and one of the workmen came in at the door the next morning. I went to a public-house in Oxford-street that night, and left a quarter before twelve o'clock. I then went home, and was taken the next morning.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

736.
WILLIAM CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of March , 3 cheeses, value 25s.; the goods of
John Ballingall Whyte
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

JOHN CONERLEY (police-constable H 135.) On the 12th of March, about a quarter past seven o'clock, I was on duty in Essex-street, Whitechapel - I saw the prisoner come out of Whitechapel, with these three cheeses on his head - I asked what he had got there? - he said, he brought them from Ratcliffe Highway, and was to meet a man at Shoreditch church with them, who would give him 1s. - I said that would not do for me, and was taking him to the station-house - he threw down the cheeses, and ran away - I left my brother officer with the cheeses - I pursued, and took the prisoner.

TIMOTHY TOOLEY
(police-constable H 32.) I was with Conerley - I took the cheeses.

JOHN BALLINGALL WHYTE. I live in Upper East Smithfield
. I lost three cheeses - I have no doubt these are mine - they are different sorts - I had had 111 of this sort in, the day before.

Prisoner's Defence. The gentleman hesitated to swear to them before the magistrate. I was standing at the London Dock gate for work, and a young man asked me to carry these cheeses in a basket to Shoreditch, and said he would meet me there - I did not know him.

WILLIAM NORMAN
(police-constable H 15.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's Office - I know the prisoner is the person.(Read.)

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Transported for Seven Years .

726.
JOHN TOFTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 4d.; the goods of
John Piper
, from his person .

JOHN PIPER. I live in Wheeler-street. I was walking with my wife at the end of Church-street, Shoreditch
, on the 5th of April, at a quarter before ten o'clock at night - I felt the prisoner's hand in my pocket - I turned round, and seized the prisoner as he was taking his hand away from my pocket - at the same time I kicked against my handkerchief on the ground - I said, "What did you touch my pocket for?" - my wife turned and said, "Here is your handkerchief" - I held the prisoner three or four minutes - he threatened if I did not let him go he would give me a b-y punch of the head - there was another with the prisoner, and he threatened me also - I let the prisoner go, and they both went about twenty yards down the street - they turned down a street, and both ran off - I turned back, and walked with my wife down Shoreditch, and met them both again - I then gave the prisoner in charge - I am positive he is the person.

SARAH PIPER
. I was with my husband. I felt something pulled from the side of me - I turned and saw this handkerchief on the ground - my husband seized the prisoner - I am sure he is the person.

HENRY CHARLES BARKER
(police-constable H 26). I took the prisoner, and have the handkerchief.
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming down the street, and this man accused me of stealing his handkerchief - a person had just rushed past me - he let me go; then met me again and gave charge of me.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Six Months

737.
EDWARD TAPPER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April , 1 pair of shoes, value 2s.; and 1 pair of buckles, set with diamonds, value 5l.; the goods of
George Warriner
, from the person of
John Ellis
.
MR. DOANE conducted the Prosecution.

GEORGE WARRINER. I am a wine-merchant . On the night of the 4th of April, I was at a party, No. 74, Newman-street - I left at three o'clock in the morning - I took off the shoes which I had worn at the party, and put my boots on - my shoes had a pair of diamond paste buckles in them - I put them and the buckles into my pocket - when I got to Hanway-street, I missed them - I returned to the house to inquire for them - I have not seen them since.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. They might have dropped from your pocket? A. Yes; I saw them last in the hall.

WILLIAM CULVERHOUSE
. I am in the service of Mr. Partington , a confectioner. I was at the house in Newman-street
- I came away with Ellis, some of the party had then left - I saw a pair of shoes on the pavement, with a pair of buckles in them - Ellis took them up - this was close to the house - the prisoner, who was the policeman, and dressed like one, came up and said to Ellis, "You had better give me those shoes, I shall probably find out the owner" - and he took them from him - I saw the prisoner again on the Saturday night afterward, (this was on the Thursday) at my master's shop - I had seen him go past, and my master went after him, and brought him back - Ellis and I said he was the man - the prisoner asked us whether we were sure of it - we said, "Yes" - and he said, "You have got that to prove at the bar."

Cross-examined. Q. What was the number of thepoliceman? A. I did not take notice of his number - I saw he had the police dress on, the blue coat - I know the police dress, and that was the dress he had on; that I am sure of - there was a linkman there, and he is here now- he had an opportunity of seeing what dress the policeman had on - Ellis did not give the shoes up to the prisoner at first - but he took hold of the toes, and Ellis had the heels - he took them at last - there was only Ellis, I, the linkman, and the prisoner there - I had gone to carry things to the ball with Ellis - I had a box on my head - my master's name was on the box - on the Saturday night afterwards, I was putting up my master's shutters, and saw the prisoner go past - my master went after him, and brought him back - my master questioned him, and he then went away - he was not detained then - it was about half-past ten o'clock - I had gone up to bed, after my master went after the prisoner, and was called down when the prisoner came.

JOHN ELLIS. I am in the employ of Mr Partington. I was at the party in Newman-street - I came away with the last witness between three and four in the morning - I picked up the shoes - the prisoner, who was the policeman, came up to me - I saw his face, and heard him speak - I know he is the man - when he came up he said, "Here, here, you must give me those shoes" - I said, I should not- he said, I had better - I said again, I should not- he asked if they were mine - I said, "No" - I asked if they were his - he said, "No" - but I had better give them to him, and probably he might find who they belonged to - they had buckles in them, which I thought were silver- the prisoner went away with them, and I went home and told my master - on the Saturday night after my fellow servant was shutting up the shop, and he saw the prisoner go by - my master put on his hat and went after him - he brought him back - we were gone to bed, and the servant came to tell us the policeman was there - my master asked me if that was the man? - I said, yes, he was - I could swear it - the prisoner said, we had better mind what we said.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite sure he said you had better mind what you said? A. Yes - I do not know what his number was - I did not think to take his number at the time - he had such a coat on as the policemen wear, but I did not take notice of the colour - I thought it was between a blue and a black - it was a great coat.

Q. Upon your oath did not you tell the magistrate it was a blue coat? A. No; I have no recollection of it - I might have said so - I did not see that he had a cape on - I will not swear whether he had one on - I know a policeman's cape - I do not think he had one on - I did not see it - I will not swear he had not one on - I did not notice whether he had an armlet on - I did not notice whether he had a lantern - I said before the magistrate that there were two linkmen there, and I thought there were - I had a box on my head with seven dozen of plates inside - my master's name was not on the box - the prisoner was brought to my master's on the Saturday night, and then let go - I saw him afterwards at the office.
JURY. Q. Had you any thing given you to drink, by the servants? A. No.

THOMAS PARTINGTON
. I am a confectioner, and live in Oxford-street - Culverhouse and Ellis are in my employ - I furnished the party with confectionary that night - in consequence of what was said to me by these two boys, I went after the prisoner on the Saturday evening - I found him in Newman-street with another policeman - I asked if either of them were on duty in Newman-street - the prisoner said he was - I asked if he knew any thing about any shoes and buckles being found - he said "No" - I then asked if he saw my boys with boxes on their heads - he said "No" - the man who was with him said he must have been blind if he did not see them - I then said the boys charged the policeman, who was on duty, with having taken the shoes - the prisoner asked where the boys were - I said at home, and he said, "I will go with you, Sir" - when we got home the boys were called down - the prisoner said to one of them, "How do you do?" - I then said to Ellis, "Here is the policeman, do you know him?" - he said Yes; he was the man who took the shoes from him - the prisoner said, "You cannot swear that" - the boy said he could - I then asked Culverhouse if he knew him - he said "Yes"- I think that was all that passed.

Cross-examined. Q. You think that what the policeman said was, "You cannot swear it?" A. Yes - he did not mention any thing about the bar - he did not say, "You had better mind what you say," not to my recollection - I have told you all that I heard, and I was there all the time - my boys are not allowed to take any refreshment when they are out - I am generally with them - I was at that party from nine till four o'clock - the boys did not tell me of it then, not till I got home.

JOHN MURPHY
. I live in Kennedy-court, and am a linkman - I was at the house in Newman-street on that night - there was another linkman there in the fore part of the night, but he went away - his name is John Herring - the prisoner was the policeman on the side the house was - he took the numbers of the coaches as they came up - there was another policeman on the other side.

Cross-examined. Q. Is that other linkman a friend of yours? A. Not a particular friend - I was dressed as I am now - the other linkman had a brown coat on - he had not an old blue policeman's coat on - he stayed till half-past nine or ten - he had a link - I had not - there was no other link man there the whole evening - I am sure there was no third linkman there, and that the other man had not an old policeman's coat on - I am a regular linkman - I was not there when the shoes were taken - the gentleman at the door sent me for two hackney coaches - I saw these boys go in and out that evening - I saw them last between two and three o'clock - they had a sort of box on their heads.
COURT. Q. You say a policeman was there, are you sure it was the prisoner? A. Yes, he was walking up and down - I should not know the other policeman.

WILLIAM EDGAR GRIMWOOD
. I am superintendent of the police - the prisoner came and surrendered himself up to me on the Monday - I stated to the magistrate that it was by the desire of the Commissioners that the case should be investigated.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the prisoner and his lodgings searched? A. Yes, there was no objection on his part tohave his place searched - he has been six weeks in the police - there has not been a better behaved man in it.
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent.

ROBERT BEECHY
(police-constable E 41.) I remember the ball in Newman-street - I was on duty with the prisoner - there were a great many persons - there were two linkmen there - Murphy was one - I saw the other there almost all night at the door, and fetching coaches - I did not observe that he had a light, but Murphy had one, which was chiefly on the steps of the door - the other linkman had a dark coat on, something like a policeman's - I was there from twenty minutes past nine o'clock till six o'clock in the morning - the prisoner behaved particularly well - I was on the other side of the street - he had his great coat on - the more I saw of him, the more he appeared a steady punctual man.
- LOVELL (police-serjeant E 15.) I saw the prisoner on the night the party was given - he had his dark brown great coat on.
COURT. Q. Has a man on duty any opportunity of putting his coat on? A. No, not without he goes into a secret place.
MR. GRIMWOOD. They are paraded before they go on duty - they are then dressed as they are for the night - they cannot change their dress.
NOT GUILTY .

738.
JULIA SMITH
and
ELIZABETH ISBESTER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of March , 2 shillings, 2 pence, 1 half-penny, and 1 farthing, the monies of
Thomas Cradock
, from his person .
MR. DOANE conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS CRADOCK. I am a pensioner . I was in Ratcliff-highway
on the 30th of March at seven o'clock in the morning - I met these two prisoners - they asked for something to drink, and I went into the Crooked Billet
with them - I gave the landlord half-a-crown, and he gave me 2s. 2 1/2d. change - I had a farthing in my pocket - I put it into my breast pocket, and went into the tap-room - Smith came in after me, whipt her hand into my breast pocket, and took the money out - the other prisoner was close to her - they ran off - I gave an alarm, and the policeman found them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you been taking any gin-hot? A. No, I did not get up till five o'clock that morning - I had been at the White Hart before I saw the prisoners - I had half a pint of ale there - I paid 3 1/2d. for it - I then saw the prisoners, and went to the Crooked Billet - I then had half-a-crown and a farthing - the gin came to 3 1/2d., and I had 2s. 2 1/2d. change - I had not seen the prisoners before - I treated them because I wanted to get rid of them.

COURT. Q. Were you talking to Smith? A. Yes; and she put her hand into my pocket and took the money - Isbester had had hold of my arm before, but she had let go before Smith took my money - they both ran away together.

BENJAMIN ROBINSON
. I am a constable. I was in the Crooked Billet, and saw the prosecutor and the two prisoners there - I saw the prosecutor change the half-crown, and they all returned into the tap-room - in about ten minutes the two prisoners came running out - I went in pursuit of them and took them.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean he was ten minutes in the tap-room with these women? A. From six to ten minutes - they had half a pint of gin at the bar, and they all drank it - whether they had any thing else I cannot say- the prosecutor is a very eccentric kind of man - I have known him take women home, fill their belly with victuals, and send them home again - they seemed very friendly together, and came in together - I do not know whether they took any thing in the tap-room.

HENRY PARKER
(police-constable K 156). I apprehended the prisoners - I found two shillings, two penny pieces, one halfpenny, and one farthing on Smith - she said it was no great catch - I was at the bar, and saw them drinking the gin - I cannot say I saw them go into the tap-room.
Smith's Defence. He gave me the 2s. to go home to his place.
NOT GUILTY .
